citation.article-title: Characterization of two novel saccharolytic, anaerobic thermophiles, Thermoanaerobacterium polysaccharolyticum sp. nov. and Thermoanaerobacterium zeae sp. nov., and emendation of the genus Thermoanaerobacterium.
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Thermoanaerobacterium zeae sp. nov.
Thermoanaerobacterium zeae (ze.ae. Gr. n. zeae of corn, describing the use of corn as a substrate for growth)
Cells are motile, Gram-positive rods and occur singly or sometimes in pairs.
Growth occurs under anaerobic conditions.
Formation of spores has not been observed.
Peritrichous flagella are present.
Grows on solid media.
Anaerobic cultures are catalase-negative and nitrate is not reduced.
Indole is not produced.
Thiosulfate, sulfate and sulfur are not reduced.
The optimum temperature is 65.70 °C.
The maximum temperature at which growth occurs is 72 °C and growth does not occur at 37 °C.
The pH range is 3.9-7.9.
The fastest doubling time observed for Thermoanaerobacterium zeae grown on glucose in a minimal media is 1.8 h for the optimum temperature range.
Growth is completely inhibited by tetracycline (50 μg ml-1), rifampicin (50 μg ml-1), kanamycin (50 μg ml-1) and erythromycin (50 μg ml-1).
Growth occurs in the presence of concentrations of 300 mM NaCl, 450 mM KCl and 150 mM NH%Cl.
The end products of fermentation on a minimal medium with 0.5% (w/v) glucose as the carbon source are ethanol (33 mM), formate (21 mM), acetate (14 mM) and lactate (7 mM).

Utilizes cracked corn, starch, xylan, glucose, arabinose, galactose, lactose, maltose, mannose, rhamnose, salicin, sucrose, trehalose, xylose, cellobiose, raffinose, melibiose, melizitose and pyruvate.
Cellulose, pectin, sorbose, mannitol, malate, fumarate, citrate, glycerol andH2/CO2 are not utilized.
The G­C content is 42 mol% as determined by the thermal denaturation method.
The type strain of Thermoanaerobacterium zeae is strain mel2T (=ATCC BAA-16T=DSM 13642T).
